PROFESSOR: A classic application
of Ampere's integral law

is to the prediction of the
magnetic field of a line
current.

Ampere's integral law
states that the integral

of the magnetic field intensity
around a closed contour C

is equal to the net
current conduction

plus displacement that
passes through the surface
S that is enclosed.

The integral of the
magnetic field intensity

around a closed contour C
is equal to the net current

that passes through the
surface S that is enclosed.

In this demonstration,
the current density

and associated fields
are at 60 hertz.

Because this frequency is
low, the time rate of change
is relatively small.

As a result, the displacement
current contribution
to Ampere's law is negligible.

In this demonstration,
a line current

essentially extends to
minus and plus infinity.

This line current passes
through a surface S enclosed

by this contour C. Ampere's
law says that there

is an integral of H around the
contour C. Symmetry requires

that only the azimuthal
component of H be non-zero

and that this component only
depend on the radial position
r.

The line integral is
simply the product

of H phi and the
circumference 2 pi r.

The surface integral
is the total current i.

H phi is inversely
proportional to r.
H phi is proportional to i.

In our experiment, the
wire is horizontal.
Here is the wire.

Ampere's law predicts the
magnetic field intensity
as it depends on r.

H sub phi is inversely
proportional to r.

This Hall effect probe measures
the magnetic field intensity.

The top trace on
the oscilloscope

is a measure of
the probe output.

The lower trace measures
the wire current.

The wire current is measured
by measuring the voltage drop
across a series 1 ohm resistor.

We measure 6 volts peak, so
the current is 6 amperes peak.

This probe measures magnetic
field intensities perpendicular
to its flat surface.

When aligned in
this direction, it

measures the z component
of magnetic field, about 0.

When aligned in
this position, it

measures the radial component of
magnetic field, again about 0.

When aligned in
this position, it

measures the phi component
of the magnetic field,

which seems to be the
only non-zero component
of magnetic field.

For our current of 6 amps,
Ampere's integral law

predicts this one overall
radial dependence for H sub phi.

Our measurements are
limited to distances,

r, small compared
to the distances

to the end of the wires or
to the return wires below.

Because the Hall effect
probe fundamentally

exploits the Lorentz
force law, it

measures the flux
density mu naught

H. A common unit for flux
density is the gauss.

We have to take
this into account
in evaluating Ampere's law.

For conversion of
units, 10,000 gauss

equal 1 tesla where the
tesla is the SI unit.

With the probe at 1 centimeter,
the measured flux density
is 1.2 gauss peak.
i is 6 amps.
r is 1 centimeter.

So we calculate mu 0
H phi to be 1.2 gauss.

Here is the data
point on our plot.

Here are some other
measured values.

We have demonstrated
the relationship

between current
through a surface S

and magnetic field intensity
integrated around the contour C
given by Ampere's integral law.
